Posts.Content: It's not wrong at all ... and a human reaction for emotional and practical reasons. BUT ... 23 years ago I sat across from a doc who told me I was not a long-term survivor and to get my affairs in order ... guess he was wrong. And that was not cancer - but something which was considered a death sentence. I'm a realist - and practical. We have to be. But it is also amazing what people and our bodies can do ... especially how powerful the mind can influence that for good or bad. As others have said - I would ask the oncologist ... but please don't let any news break your spirit ... and take care of yourself as well

Posts.Title: The Unknown

Posts.Content: Long story short: Age 49 - last December I tore my adductor off my pelvis playing ice hockey (nothing to due with cancer). MRI that confirmed that also caught enlarged prostate. PSA on 12/19/2014 was 85 - done by my regular doc (he thought test was bad). Had adductor re-attached 24 Dec 14. Next PSA on 1/6/2015 was 128. Hobbled immediately to urologist and biopsy: 5 bad cores, 4+5=9 90% 4+4=8 20% 4+4=8 30% 3+4=7 30% 4+3=7 95% Bone scan was negative and MRI negative. 25 Feb 2015 - aborted radical prostatectomy (doc took lymphs and thought for sure they were cancerous .... but tests came back negative). Classified it as Stage3. 27 Feb 2015 Lupron (6 month) and EBRT at Cleveland Clinic (Cleveland) 13 APR - 24 APR 2015. PSA 3/23/2015 24 PSA 6/25/2015 0.72 We go back in August for follow up and probably another shot. I am skating again (though not in the league) and working out as much as I can .... I was working out during the EBRT treatments and the nurse had a fit ... lol ... I didn't realize during treatments that wasn't such a good idea ... lol .... I find it hilarious my wife and I have hot flashes together ... she finds it more humorous since for years I told her I was terrified of her upcoming "change" ... lol ... I've found some great information on this site and solid people. Will check in now and then and wish everyone the best and prayers to all.

Posts.Title: Newcomer

Posts.Content: Thanks everyone. It is tough ... I'm usually the one leading people forward ... hard to ask for help or even know how to accept it ... encouraging words stated and that I need It's amazing that injury .... its very uncommon injury ... and especially for hockey ... I have to believe its my angel ... this is my 4th serious/deadly health crisis in my life for me .... and I'm still here Sorry Brandon ... by shot I meant another Lupron shot ... yes - after radiation treatment removal is more or less not an option anymore (as far as I've researched and been advised) ... the doc that attempted to take it out did right thing - at least for me ... he said tumor was a mess and taking prostate would have meant quality of life issues - and at stage/aggressiveness ... probably wouldn't make difference with obvious SBRT and hormone treatment actions ... Thanks again everyone and I will be here!

Posts.Content: Thanks guys! I think we're all on same sheet of music. And like you said ... listen to your body .... some days the workouts just aren't as intense as I'd like them to be ... but then again .... I've got to remember I'm not 18 either ... lol .... from years of contact sports I've had disks removed, a shoulder done, adductor re-attached ... lol .... And you're right ... proper exercise has to be good

Posts.Title: Working out - post treatment thoughts, experience, etc

Posts.Content: For most of my life, I've always been active and worked out. I learned (hard way lol) that its not good idea during treatment ... especially anything that is core related (hint - you'll be peeing every 3 1/2 minutes ... no kidding ... from the additional irritation to the area). But now that we've put some time and distance ... what are your experiences, advice, and medical feedback. I've been told to "give myself a break and take it easy". I get that. But it's hard for me as I am sure many. I really don't enjoy working out - I just like the results and free endorphin high (lol). BUT - if I'm going to do it .. then I'm going to do it, and push myself. I don't know if its the radiation or Lupron side effects ... but I'm achy in varying places (achy .. not pain). I was in great shape before - so I know its not respite during treatment. I find more I work out (or harder) .... less I seem to ache post workouts. I had to lay off for week due to travel ... and I seemed to ache more. What I don't want to do and am afraid of ... is work out too intensely or often. Listening to doc and nurse (take it easy, etc) I simply do 30 minutes of circuit/station training: weights, row machine and treadmill (I hate running - especially since Army .. so I just fast walk at incline) ... aside from rowing I stay away from core-isolating exercises (kettle bells, etc). My THR maintains about 130 +/- ... I'm not running marathons or a sprinter ... so that's fine with me. What do you all do? Thoughts? Am I overdoing it - or ok? Thanks!!!!!
Posts.Signature: Age 49 5 bad cores, 4+5=9 90% 4+4=8 20% 4+4=8 30% 3+4=7 30% 4+3=7 95% Bone scan, CT and MRI negative. 25 Feb 2015 - aborted radical prostatectomy. Classified it as Stage3. 27 Feb 2015 Lupron (6 month) EBRT at Cleveland Clinic (Cleveland) 13 APR - 24 APR 2015. PSA 12/19/14-85 PSA 1/6/15-128 PSA 3/23/15-24 PSA 6/25/15-0.72
Posts.Title: Working out - post treatment thoughts, experience, etc

Posts.Content: Originally Posted by goatts I've continued to work out even though they've fed me the same "take it easy" BS. I think the exercise counters the Lupron SE's. The radiation has caused me some issues but that's to be expected. Just have to roll with it. Tom Ya ... makes sense. Feel better working out. Only real issue I have is sleep. I cannot sleep more than couple hours at a time ... and its not getting up to pee thing. Not sure if that's any side affect or just nerves .... I don't have sleep apnea or anything .... never slept well past few years ... weird.
